plausible_answers.text: both a prayer as well as a method of remembering the recipe for beer in a culture with few literate people, and the ancient advice

qas.question: What did The Hymn to Gilgamesh serve as?
What may the Epic of Ninkasi have referred to?

context: The earliest known <b10_0>chemical evidence of barley beer<b10_0/> dates to <a0_0>circa <b5_0>3500–3100 BC<b5_0/><a0_0/> from the site of <b11_0>Godin Tepe<b11_0/> in the <b6_0>Zagros Mountains<b6_0/> of western <a1_0><a2_0>Iran<a2_0/><a1_0/>. Some of the earliest Sumerian writings contain references to beer; examples include a prayer to the goddess Ninkasi, known as "The Hymn to Ninkasi", which served as <b12_0>both a prayer as well as a method of remembering the recipe for beer in a culture with few literate people, and the ancient advice<b12_0/> (Fill your belly. Day and night make merry) to Gilgamesh, recorded in the Epic of Gilgamesh, by the ale-wife Siduri may, at least in part, have referred to <b13_0>the consumption of beer.<b13_0/> The <b7_0><b14_0>Ebla tablets<b14_0/><b7_0/>, discovered in <a3_0>1974<a3_0/> in Ebla, Syria, show that beer was produced in the city in 2500 BC. A fermented beverage using rice and fruit was made in China around <b8_0>7000 BC<b8_0/>. Unlike <b9_0>sake<b9_0/>, <a4_0>mould<a4_0/> was not used to saccharify the rice (amylolytic fermentation); the rice was probably prepared for fermentation by mastication or malting.
